questions.text: A 44-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She is concerned about cancer because her uncle died of metastatic melanoma 1 year ago. She has no history of serious illness and does not take any medication. She has been working in a law firm for the past 20 years and travels to the Caribbean regularly with her husband. Examination of the skin shows no abnormal moles or warts. This woman is at greatest risk of which of the following types of melanoma?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sun exposure, which likely occurred in the course of this woman's regular travel to the Caribbean, is a risk factor for desmoplastic melanoma (DM). However, DM is more common in men than women and in white individuals than dark-skinned individuals. Moreover, DM is a very rare type of melanoma, and, unlike other types of melanomas, a family history of melanoma is not a risk factor for DM. This African American woman with a family history of melanoma is at greater risk for a different type of melanoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Sun exposure, which likely occurred in the course of this woman's regular travel to the Caribbean, and a family history of melanoma are risk factors for nodular melanoma. However, nodular melanoma is more common in men than women and in white individuals than dark-skinned individuals. This African American woman is at greater risk for a different type of melanoma.
Image Description:

Nodular melanoma characteristically has a nodular appearance, but manifestations may vary.
(1) A smooth black nodule
(2) A black nodule with a rather flat appearance
(3) Ulceration
(4) An amelanotic variant

C) CORRECT:

Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is uncommon in individuals of European descent but is the most common type of melanoma in African American and Asian individuals. Unlike other types of melanomas, ALM is not associated with sun exposure. When arising from the nail bed, ALM usually manifests as a dark linear patch that widens with time (Hutchinson nail sign). On the palms, soles, and mucous membranes, ALM appears as an irregularly shaped, brown-black macule. Overall the most common type of melanoma is superficial spreading melanoma, followed by nodular melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma.
Image Description:

Irregularly shaped, brownish-black macules are visible through the nail, consistent with melanonychia. The middle finger shows pigmentation of the proximal nail fold (Hutchinson sign), consistent with subungual melanoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Sun exposure, which likely occurred in the course of this woman's regular travel to the Caribbean, and a family history of melanoma are risk factors for amelanotic melanoma. However, an amelanotic melanoma is a rare type of melanoma and is more common in white individuals than dark-skinned individuals. This African American patient is at greater risk for a different type of melanoma.
Image Description:

A solitary, red nodule on an erythematous base with slight hyperpigmentation on the bottom-right is visible.

Full-thickness excisional biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of amelanotic melanoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Sun exposure, which likely occurred in the course of this woman's regular travel to the Caribbean, and a family history of melanoma are risk factors for lentigo maligna melanoma. However, lentigo maligna melanoma is more common in white individuals than dark-skinned individuals. This African American woman is at greater risk for a different type of melanoma.
Image Description:

A 3-cm large, irregularly pigmented macule with irregular borders and surrounding mottling is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of lentigo maligna. However, dermoscopy should be performed to further assess and classify the lesion.

F) INCORRECT:

Sun exposure, which likely occurred in the course of this woman's regular travel to the Caribbean, and a family history of melanoma are risk factors for superficial spreading melanoma, which is the most common type of melanoma (accounting for 70% of all melanomas). However, superficial spreading melanoma almost always affects white individuals; dark-skinned individuals are rarely affected.
Image Description:

Upper back

An asymmetrical lesion approx. 16 mm in diameter is visible.

This lesion fulfills the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria for melanoma. The diagnosis should be confirmed by performing a full-thickness excisional biopsy.
questions.hint: Dark-skinned individuals have a significantly lower risk of melanoma than light-skinned individuals but are more commonly affected by a type of melanoma that tends to occur on the palms, soles, nail beds, and mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a skin lesion on his chest. He first noticed the lesion 2 months ago and thinks that it has increased in size since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He otherwise feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and glaucoma. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks two to three beers on the weekend. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, topical timolol, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lesion is partly elevated on palpation and does not change its form on pinching. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Malignant melanoma is an aggressive tumor of melanocytes that most commonly develops in areas that have been extensively exposed to the sun. Because malignant melanoma has a high rate of metastasis, early detection and treatment are critical. Pigmented skin lesions should be evaluated based on the ABCDE criteria. The lesion shown is asymmetric and has irregular borders with an indistinct margin. It has variable pigment and has recently increased in size. These features indicate that the most likely diagnosis is melanoma. A full-thickness excisional biopsy can confirm the diagnosis and assess Breslow depth.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatofibromas are benign, slowly growing, painless, skin-colored dermal growths that are most common on the lower extremities. In addition, unlike this patient's lesion, pinching a dermatofibroma typically produces a central dimple.
Image Description:

A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).

This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthomas are rapidly growing skin tumors that typically develop in areas that have been extensively exposed to the sun. A keratoacanthoma typically manifests as a round, erythematous nodule with a central hyperkeratotic crater. Unlike this patient's lesion, keratoacanthomas are not typically pigmented.
Image Description:

Upper body of an older female patient

A 1x1-cm round, erythematous nodule with a central crater is visible on the anterior chest wall. Keratoacanthomas arise from hair follicles or squamous cells of the skin. The main feature differentiating a keratoacanthoma from a squamous cell carcinoma is its rapid growth (keratoacanthomas tend to develop within a few weeks).

D) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna is a precancerous skin lesion that most commonly develops in areas that have been extensively exposed to the sun. This lesion typically appears as a darkly pigmented macule with irregular borders, variegated color, and so-called “island-like” speckling. Lentigo maligna tends to change gradually over years and can enlarge, change color, and become raised. This patient's lesion has rapidly increased in size and lacks peripheral speckling, making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

A 3-cm large, irregularly pigmented macule with irregular borders and surrounding mottling is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of lentigo maligna. However, dermoscopy should be performed to further assess and classify the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are the most common benign tumor in older individuals. Although these tumors can appear darker than the surrounding skin, they typically appear as multiple, sharply demarcated papules or plaques with a greasy, waxy, and so-called “stuck-on” appearance.
Image Description:

Photograph of the face of an adult patient

Two large, brown, fissured papules with a characteristic stuck-on appearance can be seen.

F) INCORRECT:

Compound melanocytic nevi, which are a type of acquired melanocytic nevus, are typically elevated and pigmented, as seen here. However, these lesions also usually have a uniform color as well as uniform borders and surfaces.
Image Description:

A round, well-demarcated, sessile papule with evenly distributed, brown pigmentation and a slightly warty surface is visible.

G) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer and can manifest in a pigmented form. However, the most common manifestation of BCC is a lesion that is pearly, indurated, nodular, nontender, and with a rolled border and central ulceration.
Image Description:

An asymmetric nodule (approx. 1 cm in diameter) with central ulceration, and rolled-out edges is visible on the right medial canthus.

This appearance is typical of nodular basal cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: New skin lesions should be evaluated according to the ABCDE criteria.

questions.text: The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. An excisional biopsy of the lesion on the chest is performed with 2-mm margins. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen confirms the diagnosis of a superficial spreading melanoma and discloses a tumor without ulcerations confined to the upper layers of the epidermis. The peripheral and deep margins of the biopsy specimen are tumor-free and there is no evidence of microsatellite lesions or lymphovascular invasion. The mitotic index is low and the depth from stratum granulosum to the lowest detectable tumor cell is 0.4 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: BRAF mutation testing and whole-body CT scan

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) should be considered only if the patient has a cutaneous melanoma with a tumor depth > 0.8 mm or certain high-risk features (e.g., ulceration, lymphovascular invasion, high mitotic rate). SLNB is not recommended for MIS and for most patients with a T1 melanoma because of the low risk of regional node metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery is primarily used to treat squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma in critical areas (e.g., eyelids, nose, ears, lips, genitalia, fingers). Although this surgical procedure may be considered for a MIS that is located on the head or neck and is of the lentigo maligna melanoma type, it is not indicated for a superficial spreading melanoma on the chest.

C) CORRECT:

The excisional biopsy for a suspected melanoma is typically performed with 1–3 mm macroscopically-negative margins. Once the diagnosis of cutaneous melanoma is histologically confirmed, wide excision for safety margins is necessary even if the margins of the excisional biopsy specimen are microscopically tumor-free. The extent of the safety margins during wide excision is primarily determined by the Breslow depth (e.g., 5–10 mm margins for a depth ≤ 1 mm, 10–20 mm margins for a depth of 1–2 mm). Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only considered if the tumor has a depth > 0.8 mm or certain high-risk features (e.g., ulceration, lymphovascular invasion, high mitotic rate).

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging to detect occult metastases (e.g., ultrasonography, whole-body CT scan) and laboratory studies (e.g., serum LDH, liver function tests) are only recommended if the patient has a cutaneous melanoma with a tumor depth ≥ 2 mm, clinical features to suggest metastasis (e.g., lymphadenopathy), or evidence of occult lymph node metastases on a sentinel lymph node biopsy. Testing for oncogenic mutations (e.g., BRAF) is only indicated for patients with metastatic melanoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Local radiotherapy is not indicated for most patients with a cutaneous melanoma and is only considered as a treatment in rare circumstances (e.g., a large lentigo maligna melanoma that cannot be treated surgically, a desmoplastic melanoma with high-risk features).
questions.hint: A melanoma confined to the upper layers of the epidermis is consistent with melanoma in situ (MIS).

questions.text: A 65-year-old Asian woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, she has had occasional night sweats during the past two months. She has not had fevers or weight loss. Seven months ago, she had an acute myocardial infarction and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, and esomeprazole. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (207 lbs); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S4. There is a nontender skin lesion near the right large toenail. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol embolism of the skin usually manifests with livedo reticularis, acrocyanosis (blue toe syndrome), or necrosis and is usually painful. This patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for myocardial infarction, which can precipitate the release of cholesterol from atherosclerotic plaques and lead to cholesterol embolization syndrome shortly after the intervention. However, this patient's PCI was seven months ago, making a cholesterol embolism unlikely.
Image Description:

Dorsal view of the right foot showing blue/purple cyanotic discoloration of the toes

B) INCORRECT:

Subungual hematomas may appear as dark-colored macules. Although this patient is taking aspirin, which increases the risk of hematoma, this diagnosis is unlikely given no history of trauma to the foot and the absence of pain and swelling of the affected nail.

C) CORRECT:

A painless, irregularly shaped, brown-black pigmented macule involving the toe and nail bed is consistent with acral lentiginous melanoma, which mainly affects dark-skinned and Asian populations. One subtype is subungual melanoma, which develops within the nail matrix and typically manifests as a longitudinal black or brown band. Moreover, periungual pigmentation of the proximal or lateral nail folds can develop (i.e., Hutchinson sign of the nail), as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient presents with a single dark-colored subungual macule, onychomycosis typically involves the whole nail and manifests as discolored (white, gray, or yellow) and brittle nails.
Image Description:

The nail plate of the left big toe has yellow discoloration extending from the distal edge and is hyperkeratotic and brittle.

This is a characteristic finding for distal subungual onychomycosis, the most common subtype of onychomycosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) may rarely involve the nail bed. However, SCCs are usually small, red tumors that may result in paronychia, pain, and bleeding.
Image Description:

Crusts and erosions can be seen on the right side of the right thumb. The nail appears completely destroyed. On the left side, a punch biopsy was taken for diagnostic purposes.

These findings suggest malignant transformation. However, histologic examination is crucial for diagnosis. In this case histology revealed subungual squamous cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an irregularly shaped, multicolored skin lesion near the toenail that is caused by a condition most commonly seen in dark-skinned and Asian populations. Bob Marley died from this condition.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for 12 hours. The pain extends from the epigastrium to the right upper quadrant and radiates to the right scapula. The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She underwent total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma 3 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. She is a farmer and spends most days working outside. Current medications include levothyroxine, omeprazole, and a multivitamin. The patient appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the right upper quadrant. Her leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3. Abdominal ultrasonography shows thickening of the gallbladder wall, without dilatation of the intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed. Pathological examination of the resected specimen shows acute cholecystitis. There is a black, ulcerated 1 x 1.5-cm mass in the fundus of the gallbladder with invasion of the gallbladder wall and adjacent lymphatic vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon is associated with smoking (which certainly increases the risk for this and other types of cancer), it metastasizes to the liver, lungs, bone, and brain, not to the gallbladder.

B) CORRECT:

Malignant melanomas most commonly spread to the lymph nodes, liver, lung, brain, and bone, but can also metastasize to unusual sites, i.e., organs that are not commonly affected by other malignancies (e.g., heart, gallbladder). Melanoma is the most common cause of gallbladder metastases in the United States. An incidentally discovered metastatic lesion can be the initial manifestation of malignant melanoma and in most cases, a careful evaluation will reveal the primary tumor site (typically skin; less commonly mucous membranes). Up to 5% of patients with metastatic melanoma, however, will not have a primary tumor on evaluation (melanoma of unknown primary).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which makes a recurrence possible. However, papillary thyroid carcinoma most frequently metastasizes to the neck lymph nodes. Distant metastases are rare and typically involve the lungs and bones, not the gallbladder.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is associated with certain hormone-producing neoplasias of endocrine glands (e.g., the thyroid, parathyroid, and endocrine pancreatic gland), and as this patient has a history of thyroid cancer, a recurrence is possible. However, MEN is associated with medullary, not papillary, thyroid carcinoma, and none of the malignancies that are associated with MEN metastasize to the gallbladder.

E) INCORRECT:

Although squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus is associated with smoking (which certainly increases the risk for this and other types of cancer), it metastasizes to local lymph nodes, the liver, and lungs, not to the gallbladder.
questions.hint: The presence of a black and ulcerated gallbladder mass with invasion of the gallbladder wall and lymphatics suggests malignancy. UV exposure (e.g., from agricultural work) is the primary risk factor for the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because he is worried about a mole on his right forearm. He has had the mole for several years, but it has grown in size in the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented plaque with irregular borders and small area of ulceration. Histopathologic analysis of a full-thickness excisional biopsy confirms the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Invasion of which of the following layers of skin carries the highest risk of mortality for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells in the stratum corneum are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to this layer are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells extending into the reticular dermis have a high potential for metastatic spread, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells extending into the papillary dermis have metastatic potential, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, it is not the deepest layer of the skin and invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

D) CORRECT:

The hypodermis (subcutis) is the deepest layer of the skin, and melanoma mortality is directly correlated with tumor thickness. Due to variability in the thickness of skin compartments among different individuals, tumor thickness does not always correspond with skin layer invasion. However, in this patient, it is likely that a tumor extending into the hypodermis is thicker than a tumor in a more superficial layer. Breslow depth is an important prognostic factor used for melanoma staging and to determine the safety margin of a wide local excision.
Image Description:

The skin is composed of the cutis (epidermis and dermis) and the subcutis.

- The epidermis has five layers: stratum corneum, lucidum, granulosum, spinosum, and basale.
- The dermis has two layers: papillary and reticular dermis.
- The subcutis contains fat and neurovascular structures.

E) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells in the stratum basale are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to the stratum basale are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.
questions.hint: Tumor thickness is one of the most important prognostic factors for malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has no history of serious medical illness. She appears well. Physical examination shows several hundred pigmented lesions on the back and upper extremities. A photograph of the lesions is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk of developing a tumor with which of the following findings?

choices.text: PAS-positive T cells with cerebriform nuclei
S100-positive epithelioid cells with fine granules
Spindle endothelial cells forming slit-like spaces
Pale, round cells with palisading nuclei

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycosis fungoides is caused by cutaneous infiltration of PAS-positive malignant T-helper cells with cerebriform nuclei. Affected patients may present with scaly, pruritic, well-demarcated skin plaques and patches, but it is not associated with FAMMM.

B) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma presents with atypical keratinocytes forming keratin pearls. Cutaneous SCC lesions frequently ulcerate and form granulation tissue that easily bleeds- neither of which is present in this patient. Atypical keratinocytes with keratin pearls are not associated with FAMMM.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with FAMMM have an increased risk of developing malignant melanoma. Staining of the malignant cells shows epithelioid cells expressing S100 protein and fine granules in the cytoplasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma consists of spindle endothelial cells forming slit-like spaces. It usually presents with violaceous plaques in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). It is not associated with FAMMM.

E) INCORRECT:

Signet ring cell carcinoma consists of mucin-filled cells with peripheral nuclei. It and other types of gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas (e.g., colorectal, liver, pancreas) may be associated with new seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trélat sign). It is not associated with FAMMM.

F) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) appears as a pearly lesion with rolled borders, central ulcerations, and telangiectasias. Lesions are most commonly seen on the face but may occur on the lower back. An increased risk of developing BCC is associated with xeroderma pigmentosum, not FAMMM.
questions.hint: The presence of multiple atypical nevi is consistent with familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome (FAMMM), a familial syndrome that carries an increased risk of developing malignant transformation of a nevus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Her husband noticed a “weird-looking” dark skin lesion on her hand 3 months ago. She has not seen any changes in the lesion since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has light skin but no freckles. There is an elevated, symmetrical skin lesion with uniform borders on the medial aspect of the patient's left hand. The lesion measures 5 mm in diameter and is dark brown. Dermoscopy shows a brown pigment network with scattered grey and reddish spots. Which of the following is the strongest indicator for performing an excisional biopsy?

choices.text: No change in the lesion over the past 3 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Melanocytic skin lesions that meet at least one ABCDE criterion should raise suspicion for malignant transformation and merit consideration of full-thickness excisional biopsy with histological examination. The mixture of colors in this patient's skin lesion meets criterion C (color variegation, e.g., different shades of brown, black, red, white, and/or blue).

Tumor thickness, as determined from the Breslow thickness (measured in mm), is an important prognostic factor in melanoma.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

B) INCORRECT:

According to criterion D (diameter) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions measuring more than 6 mm should prompt further diagnostic steps. The diameter of this patient's lesion is 5 mm and, therefore, not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

According to criterion E (evolution) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that change in size, shape, or color should prompt further diagnostic steps. A skin lesion that has not changed noticeably over time, as seen here, is not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

According to criterion B (borders) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that have irregular borders should prompt further diagnostic steps. Uniform borders, as seen here, are not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

According to criterion A (asymmetry) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that are asymmetrical should raise suspicion for malignancy. This patient's skin lesion is symmetrical and, therefore, not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

F) INCORRECT:

Malignancies such as nodular melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and basal cell carcinoma typically manifest as papules or nodules (i.e., elevated efflorescence). If a melanocytic skin lesion develops from a macule to a papule, it meets the E (evolution) criteria and should prompt further diagnostic steps. However, in general, neither an elevated nor nonelevated skin lesion is an indicator of malignancy. Furthermore, this patient's skin lesion has not changed noticeably over time.
questions.hint: A pigment network is characteristic of a melanocytic lesion. Consider the ABCDE criteria to identify signs of malignant melanoma: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with an ulcerated lesion on his right foot that has “been there awhile.”
Physical examination confirms the presence of a pigmented lesion with a small ulceration on the plantar surface of his right foot (figure). The patient also has diminished bilateral dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, diminished sensation in both ankles, and an absent ankle reflex. His glycated hemoglobin level is 9.8% (reference range, 3.8–6.4).
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Refer for electromyography and nerve conduction studies
Obtain an excisional biopsy of the skin lesion
Perform a shave biopsy of the skin lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nerve studies can help to further characterize neuropathy in patients with diabetes mellitus and neuropathic ulceration, but the workup for possible melanoma takes priority.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy can be appropriate for a wart but should not be used to treat a lesion that is more typical of a melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the ankle-brachial index can clarify the severity and location of stenoses in patients with peripheral vascular disease, it would not clarify the cause of a multicolored plantar lesion.

D) CORRECT:

A multicolored lesion with an irregular border is consistent with a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Lesions that are asymmetric, have irregular borders, demonstrate color variation, or exceed 6 mm in diameter are considered suspicious. In addition, any pigmented lesion that becomes darker or lighter in color, increases in size, becomes raised, ulcerates, or starts to itch or bleed should arouse suspicion for malignancy. Plantar and subungual sites account for two-thirds of melanomas of the foot and for 3% to 15% of all cutaneous melanomas. The diagnosis at these sites is often delayed or missed.

A major pitfall in the early diagnosis of lesions that have features of malignant melanoma is the failure to obtain a satisfactory biopsy specimen. When melanoma is suspected, excisional biopsy with a 1- to 3-mm margin is preferred.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in the management of a skin lesion that has features suggestive of melanoma is to obtain an excisional biopsy.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 2 patients with acral lentiginous melanoma (image 1: right midfoot sole; image 2: right forefoot sole)

Both lesions are black-brown pigmented macules with nodular and ulcerated components, fulfilling the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

E) INCORRECT:

Shave biopsies should be avoided in this setting, because they can compromise both pathologic diagnosis and a complete assessment of tumor thickness. Furthermore, the extreme thickness of the plantar epidermis limits the usefulness of shave biopsy as a diagnostic tool.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man reports moderate throbbing pain as well as itchiness under and around the nail of his left thumb. These symptoms have been worsening over the past year. This week, he also noticed the development of bleeding and spotting around the nail fold. He has no history of trauma.
Physical examination reveals a dark, pigmented area of discoloration under the nail bed and associated periungual pigmentation (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Melanonychia striata is a benign linear band of pigmentation of the nail plate caused by melanin. It is also commonly found in dark-skinned people.

B) INCORRECT:

A subungual hematoma is usually confined under the nail and is associated with recent trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

A pigmented basal-cell carcinoma, a variant of basal-cell carcinoma, does not commonly arise near the nail and would be a papule with a pearly border and telangiectasias.

D) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a papule with a central keratinous plug found on sun-exposed areas of the body. Some keratoacanthomas can resemble squamous-cell carcinoma. Excisional biopsy is recommended to ascertain the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Acral lentiginous melanoma is one of four subtypes of malignant melanoma, along with superficial spreading, nodular, and lentigo maligna melanoma. Acral lentiginous melanoma accounts for fewer than 5% of melanomas, but it is the most common type of melanoma in dark-skinned people. The only melanoma subtype not associated with extreme sun exposure, it is found on the palms and soles, in the nail beds, and occasionally in mucous membranes. Periungual pigmentation, the so-called Hutchinson sign, is associated with acral lentiginous melanoma.

Key learning point: A dark, pigmented macular lesion under the nail bed with associated periungual pigmentation should raise suspicion for acral lentiginous melanoma.
Image Description:

Linear brown striations are visible on the lateral side of the nail plate of the right thumb. A periungual, flat, asymmetrical, brown-black pigmented macule of approx. 1-cm diameter with an irregular border is visible.

The combination of these manifestations is referred to as Hutchinson sign and is highly suggestive of subungual melanoma.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman reports a changing mole (figure). She has a history of being sunburned as a child.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Perform an elliptical excision with 1-cm margins
Take a photograph, reassure the patient, and schedule a reevaluation in 3 months
Perform a biopsy on a portion of the lesion
Perform a biopsy that samples the entire lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elliptical excision with 1-cm margins would be appropriate only if the diagnosis was already established and a 1-cm margin was appropriate according to the original histopathology and current treatment guidelines. It is not recommended as the initial diagnostic test. Although it would allow for assessment of the lesion in its entirety, excision with large margins and the subsequent closure could distort the anatomy and affect local lymphatic drainage. If the lesion turns out to be a deep melanoma that requires sentinel-lymph-node mapping and biopsy, having removed the lesion with such large margins could interfere with lymphatic drainage and result in an inaccurate sentinel-node procedure. The correct definitive surgical margins are determined by tumor depth and may range from 5 mm to 2 cm.

B) INCORRECT:

Monitoring the lesion for change is not appropriate for evaluating and managing suspected melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of only a portion of the lesion is not recommended because melanomas are not uniform. Some areas may show regression of the tumor and appear less invasive or possibly benign. Such sampling error could result in misdiagnosis or inadequate staging of the melanoma.

D) CORRECT:

Melanoma should be suspected in pigmented lesions with a concerning appearance, such as irregular borders and irregular pigmentation, especially in patients with risk factors for melanoma, such as a history of sunburns.

When feasible, the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for a patient with suspected melanoma is a biopsy in which the entire lesion is removed, either by excisional biopsy or a scoop shave (saucerization). A 1-cm margin would not necessarily be included at the time of initial diagnostic excision, because the margin should be determined by the features of the histopathology. Performing excisional biopsy or a scoop shave biopsy of the entire lesion allows pathologists to assess the lesion in its entirety, confirm the diagnosis, and obtain important prognostic information in order to determine what margin is required for reexcision and whether a sentinel-lymph-node biopsy needs to be performed.

Key learning point: In a patient with suspected melanoma, the most appropriate next step is complete removal of the entire lesion via biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Treating the lesion with liquid nitrogen is not appropriate for managing suspected melanoma.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents for evaluation of an asymptomatic skin lesion on her right shin that she first noticed a few weeks ago and thinks is growing. Examination reveals fair skin with lots of freckles and numerous, variably sized melanocytic nevi on the trunk and extremities. On the right shin is a pigmented lesion (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Talon noir is a black spot that occurs on the heel or foot due to friction or trauma (such as from playing tennis or soccer). Because of its black color, it may resemble melanoma. It does not typically occur on the shin.

B) INCORRECT:

Atypical fibroxanthomas are malignant tumors that occur on the head and neck in older patients, typically in areas of substantial sun damage. These tumors tend to grow rapidly and may resemble basal-cell or squamous-cell carcinomas. Pigmentation is unusual.

C) INCORRECT:

Ink-spot lentigos are dark black, small, jagged macules in areas of intense sun exposure, resembling droplets of ink from quills or fountain pens; they are benign but are a marker of intense ultraviolet exposure.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's skin lesion is 6 mm in size, multicolored, and asymmetric with an irregular border; together, these features make malignant melanoma the most likely diagnosis.

The “ABCDE” mnemonic describes the worrisome features of an atypical pigmented lesion: (A) asymmetry, (B) border irregularities, (C) color variegation, (D) diameter >6 mm, and (E) evolution. Evolution describes any longitudinal change in physical examination findings, noted by either the patient or the clinician, that suggests the need for biopsy. Such changes include rapid growth, changes in the border, erythema along the edges, bleeding or itching, regression of pigment, or ulceration.

The legs are a common site of melanoma, particularly in women; the back may be more common in men. Risk factors for melanoma include sun exposure, use of tanning booths, fair skin, the presence of multiple banal and clinically atypical nevi, and family history of melanoma.

Key learning point: A multicolored melanocytic skin lesion with irregular borders in a patient with sun-damaged skin is most consistent with a diagnosis of malignant melanoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are benign, waxy-appearing, gray-brown growths that appear to be stuck onto the skin. They are not normally flat and are often somewhat scaly, but in some cases, they can be clinically challenging to distinguish from melanoma.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man reports a brown longitudinal line on his right thumbnail. He first noticed it about 8 months ago but does not recall any precipitating injury. The line has not changed over time, and the nail is asymptomatic.
On examination, there is a 1-mm-wide, dark-brown longitudinal band across the nail plate of the right thumb (figure) and similar, fainter bands on several other digits. No onycholysis or subungual debris is evident.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Counsel the patient to protect the affected nails from trauma
Obtain a nail clipping for fungal culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Suspicion for a concomitant fungal infection would be low in the absence of onycholysis or subungual debris. Thus, there is no need to obtain a nail clipping for fungal culture or to empirically start antifungal treatment for onychomycosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Clinical findings alone cannot distinguish longitudinal melanonychia from subungual melanoma, but observation alone (without biopsy) is most appropriate in the absence of features that raise suspicion for subungual melanoma. In this case, the patient has involvement of a high-risk digit (the thumb), but other digits are also involved, and there are no other concerning features. Observation without referral for further evaluation or biopsy is therefore appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Trauma can cause nail changes such as a subungual hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the nail bed and the nail plate that appears as dark-red, pink, or brown pigmentation under the nail. However, the appearance of this patient’s nail lesion is not consistent with a subungual hematoma. Unlike in longitudinal melanonychia, the pigment of a subungual hematoma does not extend from the base of the nail to the free edge. Instead, the pigment is focal and grows only as the nail grows out. Reassurance is adequate in these cases, as in cases of benign longitudinal melanonychia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has benign longitudinal melanonychia, a nail disorder characterized by a longitudinal band of pigment that extends from the base of the nail (the nail matrix) to the free edge of the nail. It is caused by the production of melanin by melanocytes in the nail matrix and is common in patients with darker skin tones. The bands in benign longitudinal melanonychia tend to be narrow in width (<3 mm), to be even and symmetric in appearance, and to affect several digits without affecting the proximal nail fold. Patients with benign longitudinal melanonychia can be reassured and monitored for changes in the pigmentation.

Clinical findings alone cannot distinguish longitudinal melanonychia from subungual melanoma, but observation alone (without biopsy) is most appropriate in the absence of the following features that raise suspicion for subungual melanoma:

• Involvement of a single digit, usually the thumb, big toe, or index finger
• Pigmented band ≥3 mm in width
• Irregular or blurred borders to the band
• Brown-black discoloration of the proximal nail fold (Hutchinson sign)
• Rapid increase in the size of the pigmented band
• Family history of melanoma
• Associated dystrophy of the nail

In this case, the patient has involvement of a high-risk digit (the thumb), but other digits are also involved, and there are no other concerning features. Observation without referral for further evaluation or biopsy is therefore appropriate.

Key learning point: Longitudinal melanonychia is usually benign if the bands of pigmentation are <3 mm, are even in color and appearance, affect more than one digit, and do not affect the proximal nail fold.

E) INCORRECT:

Suspicion for a concomitant fungal infection would be low in the absence of onycholysis or subungual debris. Thus, there is no need to obtain a nail clipping for fungal culture or to empirically start antifungal treatment for onychomycosis.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an itchy skin lesion on his left forearm that he first noticed 6 months ago. Since its appearance, the lesion has grown horizontally and changed shape. He has a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with methotrexate. He has lived in Arizona and worked at a gardening center for the past 40 years. His father died of “skin problems” at the age of 68 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm shows an asymmetrical, 1.5-cm plaque with irregular, scalloped borders, variegated brown and black pigmentation, and central ulceration. Skin biopsy establishes the diagnosis. Which of the following features of this patient's skin lesion most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ulceration is an important negative prognostic feature of malignant melanoma. Additional negative prognostic features of malignant melanoma are increased Breslow depth, high mitotic rate, melanoma microsatellitosis, and malignant cells at the margins of the biopsy specimen.

B) INCORRECT:

A diameter > 6 mm raises concern for malignant melanoma, as outlined in the ABCDE criteria, but it is not a negative prognostic feature in melanoma. Rather, the thickness of the tumor, measured from the top of the stratum granulosum or the ulcer base to the deepest tumor cell (i.e., Breslow depth), is a negative prognostic factor in malignant melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Irregular borders raise concern for malignant melanoma, as outlined in the ABCDE criteria. However, border irregularity is not a negative prognostic feature in melanoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the lesion's location is not an important negative prognostic feature, melanomas in certain locations, such as the back, chest, head, and neck are associated with a poorer prognosis. This patient's lesion is located on the forearm, suggesting a more favorable prognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Color variegation is a characteristic that raises concern for malignant melanoma, as outlined in the ABCDE criteria. However, color variegation is not a negative prognostic feature in melanoma.

F) INCORRECT:

The plaque-like morphology of this patient's skin lesion is characteristic of superficial spreading melanoma (SSM). Unlike nodular melanomas, which rapidly grow vertically and have a poor prognosis, SSMs exhibit relatively slow horizontal growth and therefore have a more favorable prognosis.
questions.hint: The patient's skin lesion fulfills the ABCDE criteria (Asymmetry, Border irregularities, Color variegation, Diameter > 6 mm, and Evolving in size, shape, and/or color), raising concern for malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a skin lesion on his neck. He says that he has had the lesion “forever” but that his partner encouraged him to seek medical attention. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. The patient has light skin but no freckles. There is a 4-mm, symmetrical, homogeneously black lesion on the left side of his neck. It has scalloped borders and a sandpaper-like texture. There is mild erythema around the lesion. Which of the following is the strongest indicator for performing an excisional biopsy of the lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) and keratoacanthoma generally manifest with surrounding erythema and most commonly occur on areas of sun-exposed skin. This patient's skin lesion does not have central ulceration or bleed easily (typically seen in cSCC) and there is no history of rapid growth (typically seen in keratoacanthoma). Moreover, his lesion raises concern for melanoma, for which surrounding erythema is not a strong indication to perform an excisional biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

According to criterion D (diameter) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions > 6 mm in diameter should prompt further evaluation. The diameter of this patient's lesion is only 4 mm and, therefore, not a strong indication for an excisional biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

According to criterion C (color) of the ABCDE criteria for melanoma, skin lesions that have a varied color (e.g., different shades of brown, black, red, white, and/or blue) are suspicious for malignancy. The homogeneous black shade of this patient's skin lesion does not meet this criterion and is, therefore, not an indication for an excisional biopsy.

D) CORRECT:

Skin lesions that meet at least one ABCDE criterion should raise suspicion for malignant transformation and merit consideration of full-thickness excisional biopsy with histopathologic examination. This patient's skin lesion meets criterion B (border) in so far as it has scalloped (irregular) borders.

Tumor thickness, as determined from the Breslow thickness (measured in mm), is an important prognostic factor in melanoma.
Image Description:

Composite image showing 6 patients with superficial spreading melanoma

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

E) INCORRECT:

Lesions with a sandpaper-like texture are typical of actinic keratosis. Being precancerous in nature, actinic keratoses are not typically biopsied, but are treated with cryotherapy, 5-fluorouracil, or photodynamic therapy. Since this patient's lesion has been present for a very long time and is highly pigmented, it is unlikely to be an actinic keratosis.
questions.hint: This patient's lesion is concerning for malignant melanoma. Consider the ABCDE criteria for evaluation of a pigmented skin lesion. A - asymmetry; B - border; C - color; D - diameter; E - evolution.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with an ulcerated lesion on his right foot that has “been there awhile.” Physical examination confirms the presence of a pigmented lesion with a small ulceration on the plantar surface of his right foot (figure). The patient also has diminished bilateral dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, diminished sensation in both ankles, and an absent ankle reflex. His glycated hemoglobin level is 9.8% (reference range, 3.8–6.4). What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Refer for electromyography and nerve conduction studies
Obtain an excisional biopsy of the skin lesion
Perform a shave biopsy of the skin lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nerve studies can help to further characterize neuropathy in patients with diabetes mellitus and neuropathic ulceration, but the workup for possible melanoma takes priority.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy can be appropriate for a wart but should not be used to treat a lesion that is more typical of a melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the ankle-brachial index can clarify the severity and location of stenoses in patients with peripheral vascular disease, it would not clarify the cause of a multicolored plantar lesion.

D) CORRECT:

A multicolored lesion with an irregular border is consistent with a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Lesions that are asymmetric, have irregular borders, demonstrate color variation, or exceed 6 mm in diameter are considered suspicious. In addition, any pigmented lesion that becomes darker or lighter in color, increases in size, becomes raised, ulcerates, or starts to itch or bleed should arouse suspicion for malignancy. Plantar and subungual sites account for two-thirds of melanomas of the foot and for 3% to 15% of all cutaneous melanomas. The diagnosis at these sites is often delayed or missed.

A major pitfall in the early diagnosis of lesions that have features of malignant melanoma is the failure to obtain a satisfactory biopsy specimen. When melanoma is suspected, excisional biopsy with a 1- to 3-mm margin is preferred.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in the management of a skin lesion that has features suggestive of melanoma is to obtain an excisional biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Shave biopsies should be avoided in this setting, because they can compromise both pathologic diagnosis and a complete assessment of tumor thickness. Furthermore, the extreme thickness of the plantar epidermis limits the usefulness of shave biopsy as a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man reports moderate throbbing pain as well as itchiness under and around the nail of his left thumb. These symptoms have been worsening over the past year. This week, he also noticed the development of bleeding and spotting around the nail fold. He has no history of trauma. Physical examination reveals a dark, pigmented area of discoloration under the nail bed and associated periungual pigmentation (figure). Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Melanonychia striata is a benign linear band of pigmentation of the nail plate caused by melanin. It is also commonly found in dark-skinned people.

B) INCORRECT:

A subungual hematoma is usually confined under the nail and is associated with recent trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

A pigmented basal-cell carcinoma, a variant of basal-cell carcinoma, does not commonly arise near the nail and would be a papule with a pearly border and telangiectasias.

D) INCORRECT:

Keratoacanthoma is a papule with a central keratinous plug found on sun-exposed areas of the body. Some keratoacanthomas can resemble squamous-cell carcinoma. Excisional biopsy is recommended to ascertain the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Acral lentiginous melanoma is one of four subtypes of malignant melanoma, along with superficial spreading, nodular, and lentigo maligna melanoma. Acral lentiginous melanoma accounts for fewer than 5% of melanomas, but it is the most common type of melanoma in dark-skinned people. The only melanoma subtype not associated with extreme sun exposure, it is found on the palms and soles, in the nail beds, and occasionally in mucous membranes. Periungual pigmentation, the so-called Hutchinson sign, is associated with acral lentiginous melanoma.

Key learning point: A dark, pigmented macular lesion under the nail bed with associated periungual pigmentation should raise suspicion for acral lentiginous melanoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. Her husband noticed a “weird-looking” dark skin lesion on her hand 3 months ago. She has not seen any changes in the lesion since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. There is an elevated, symmetrical skin lesion with uniform borders on the medial aspect of the patient's left hand. The lesion measures 5 mm in diameter. Dermoscopy shows a brown pigment network with scattered grey and reddish spots. Which of the following is the strongest indicator for performing an excisional biopsy?

choices.text: No change in the lesion over the past 3 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Of the ABCDE criteria of skin lesions concerning for melanoma, the lesion in image 1 fulfills only criteria A (asymmetry) and B (border irregularity). The lesions in images 2–6 fulfill criteria A, B, and C (color variegation). The lesion in image 2 also fulfills criterion D (diameter > 6 mm), which cannot be assessed in the other images in the absence of a measurement device. Criterion E (evolution: changes over time) cannot be assessed on single images.

B) INCORRECT:

According to criterion D (diameter) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions measuring more than 6 mm should prompt further diagnostic steps. The diameter of this patient's lesion is 5 mm and, therefore, not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

According to criterion E (evolution) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that change in size, shape, or color should prompt further diagnostic steps. A skin lesion that has not changed noticeably over time, as seen here, is not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

According to criterion B (borders) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that have irregular borders should prompt further diagnostic steps. Uniform borders, as seen here, are not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

According to criterion A (asymmetry) of the ABCDE criteria of melanoma, skin lesions that are asymmetrical should raise suspicion for malignancy. This patient's skin lesion is symmetrical and, therefore, not an indication for performing an excisional biopsy.

Cryotherapy can be appropriate for a wart but should not be used to treat a lesion that is more typical of a melanoma.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents to the ED with right ankle pain after inverting the ankle stepping off a curb. On examination, you notice abnormality on her great toenail (shown in photograph). She denies pain or prior similar findings and states it has been there for 3 months. She cannot remember any trauma to the nail, but states she may not have remembered a minor injury. The remainder of her skin examination is unremarkable. X-rays of the ankle are normal Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Arrange urgent dermatology or surgical referral for biopsy of the nail matrix and bed
Reassure the patient that the finding is consistent with subungual hematoma and advise observation
Prescribe topical antifungal therapy for possible onychomycosis
Trim the top portion of the nail and  arrange PCP follow up to observe for migration of pigment with regrowth
Reassure the patient that the finding represents benign melanonychia and requires no further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — Subungual melanoma presents as irregular longitudinal melanonychia, sometimes with pigment extension onto the adjacent skin (Hutchinson sign). It is frequently misdiagnosed as hematoma or fungal infection. Prompt referral for complete nail unit biopsy is essential for diagnosis and definitive management, as delayed recognition leads to poor outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

Subungual hematomas usually result from trauma, are uniformly dark, and migrate distally with nail growth. The absence of a clear trauma history, irregular pigmentation, and extension to the nail fold make hematoma unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Onychomycosis typically causes nail thickening, brittleness, and yellow-white discoloration rather than a dark pigmentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Observation for pigment migration may help confirm subungual hematoma but is inappropriate when features suggest melanoma. Irregular, persistent pigmentation and periungual extension require immediate evaluation rather than serial observation.

E) INCORRECT:

Benign melanonychia typically presents as uniform, narrow, longitudinal pigmentation that remains stable over time. In contrast, irregular width, color variation, and pigment extension to the nail fold suggest subungual melanoma. Reassurance rather than further investigation risks missing a potentially aggressive malignancy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of extensive sun exposure presents for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on his upper back. He states the lesion has been present for years but his wife noted it has become darker and slightly larger over the past 4 months. Physical examination reveals an 8-mm macule with an irregular border and variable black and brown pigmentation. Which of the following is the most important historical feature when assessing this patient's risk for melanoma?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asymmetry and an irregular border are key features in the ABCDE mnemonic for melanoma. While important, these are static morphological features. Benign atypical (dysplastic) nevi can also be asymmetrical and have irregular borders. A different criterion is a more powerful predictor of malignancy than a static feature like asymmetry, which may have been present for years.

B) CORRECT:

Among the clinical features of melanoma, evolution or a recent change in a mole's appearance is the most critical indicator of malignancy. The ABCDE mnemonic (Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter > 6 mm, Evolving) is used to screen for melanoma, but the 'E' for Evolving is the most sensitive clinical finding. A lesion that has been stable for years and then begins to change in size, shape, color, or elevation is highly suspicious. This patient’s report that the lesion has become darker and larger over four months is the most concerning feature, as it signifies active and recent growth, a hallmark of malignant transformation. This history prompts urgent evaluation, typically with excisional biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

The upper back is a common location for melanoma, particularly in men, due to intermittent, intense sun exposure. While this location increases the patient's baseline risk and is epidemiologically significant, it is not a diagnostic feature of the lesion itself. The characteristics of the lesion are far more important in assessing risk than its anatomical site.

D) INCORRECT:

A diameter greater than 6 mm (the size of a pencil eraser) is one of the ABCDE criteria for melanoma. While this finding raises suspicion, it is not the most important feature. Many benign nevi, such as congenital or dysplastic nevi, can be larger than 6 mm and remain stable for life. Conversely, some early melanomas may be smaller than 6 mm when they are first detected.
questions.hint: While all the ABCDE criteria for melanoma are important for identifying a suspicious lesion, one criterion is considered the single most sensitive feature for malignancy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of extensive sun exposure during his career as a landscaper presents for a routine skin examination. He is concerned about a dark spot on his upper back that his wife says has been growing over the past year. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The lesion is non-tender and firm to palpation. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Sentinel lymph node mapping and biopsy
Shave biopsy of the entire lesion
Punch biopsy of the darkest area

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The decision to perform this procedure is based on the histologic features of the primary tumor. This step would be premature without a confirmed diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A shave biopsy is a common dermatologic procedure, but it is generally contraindicated for lesions highly suspicious for melanoma. A standard shave biopsy is often too superficial and may transect the base of the tumor. This prevents an accurate measurement of the full tumor thickness, which can lead to understaging and inadequate subsequent treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation with serial dermoscopy can be appropriate for monitoring some atypical nevi that have a low suspicion for melanoma. However, this lesion exhibits multiple high-risk clinical features (the ABCDE criteria) and has a reported history of growth, making observation with serial dermoscopy an inappropriate step at this point.

D) CORRECT:

The gold standard for suspected melanoma is a full-thickness excisional biopsy with 1–3 mm surgical margins. This technique removes the entire lesion, allowing the pathologist to accurately measure the Breslow depth (tumor thickness), which is the single most important prognostic factor. An adequate sample also allows for assessment of other crucial histologic features like ulceration and mitotic rate, which are essential for accurate staging and determining subsequent management, such as the need for wider re-excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

While a punch biopsy provides a full-thickness sample, it only captures a small portion of the lesion. This creates a significant risk of sampling error, as the punch may miss the deepest or most invasive area of the tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's lesion has multiple features concerning for melanoma, such as asymmetry, irregular border, color variegation, diameter >6 mm, and evolution.
